*How to get a Beaclon*
Monster Rancher Metropolis: Monster Rancher 2 Archive (PSOne): Monster Types: Beaclon/Worm: *How to get a Beaclon*
By Beaclon on Wednesday, April 19, 2000 - 04:53 pm:

Requirements for Beaclon: You need any kind of Worm, It needs to be C rank or lower, It must be feed 30 Cup Jellys, It must be over 4 years old, must have 80 or higher loyalty, And finally must be Very Well on the 4th week of June.

By pono on Thursday, May 11, 2000 - 03:07 pm:

Do you have to feed it exactly 30 cup jellys or at least 30. I've been trying to get it for a while but it aint working.

By Tony on Thursday, May 11, 2000 - 03:29 pm:

More than 30 is OK. Everything else should be OK. It took me 2 tries to get my Beaclon, so don't get discouraged.

By Lisa Shock on Thursday, May 11, 2000 - 05:32 pm:

You can feed more than 30 cup jellies, 30 is the minimum.
It must never have been stressed. The real trick here is to manage the stress against the spoiling.
First of all, check your monter's form. If it's skinny or slim, feed candy. If it's fat give it powder. This will help it not get stressed too easily. Check the form at least once a month. I got a worm from a CD whose starting form was skinny. I fed one candy during each of it's two first weeks on the ranch and it stayed at a normal weight for about a year, returning to skinny as a chronic condition. Managing stress also means making sure your monster gets enough rest. I like about 1 week of rest for each 3 weeks of work. Don't send them on expeditions, there's just no point in risking them for a few items. I always send them on errantry during week 1, so they get fed regularly. If I know they'll be going on errantry, I always rest them the week before (week 4 of prior month) and feed both nuts oil and mint just before sending them. I would only send the worm on a maximum of 3 errantries, the first at about 1 year of age. I also held back on battles, waiting until I was sure the worm's stats were high enough to win easily. As always, save right before a battle so you can reset in case of injury.
The spoiling part is where most ranchers fall down. The cup jellies slightly spoil the monsters, so after a few months you're style can shift from even to fond without any instances of praise and this affects loyalty. Too much spoiling and your loyalty won't get over 55. The trick is to start feeding the smoked snake as your syle gets more "fond". I found that mint and snake together seem to work well, and had a 12 point loyalty jump once at the first feeding of the combo at about one and a half years of age. The last two years of my worm's life as a worm had me rotating feeding mint, snakes, candy, nuts oil (he kept asking for it), and the occasional mango at least once a month, sometimes using items every two weeks. My loyalty was at 90 very quickly and once raised would only fluctuate from 98-94, never dropping below 92 and I never had stress or spoiling.
Hope this helps!

By Lisa Shock on Thursday, May 11, 2000 - 05:35 pm:

It took me three tries, although I did use my "failures" in combination to get a better final monster. I did wind up discarding one combo where the offspring hated cup jellies, that seemed just WAY too hard!

By Lisa Shock on Saturday, May 20, 2000 - 07:18 pm:

I didn't get my beaclon until I understood this info. (starting with a skinny monster didn't help either, but it was a choice between that one and one that hated cup jelly...)

By Kurasu Soratubo on Sunday, May 21, 2000 - 10:11 am:

I have to disagree with that one, Lisa. My worm got stressed for short periods of time, I'm certain of it. I just cured it as quickly as it came up, and I was able to get the Beaclon out. It can't be spoiled or stressed at the time that it's hatching, I know that much, but I'm almost positive that my successful try was stressed once in its youth. I just upped the mint leaves, and it never happened again.

I think the main reason it can't get spoiled and stressed is that it has to live for 4 years, and spoil/stress can easily lower that lifespan. Especially stress.

By Lisa Shock on Sunday, May 21, 2000 - 11:36 am:

I had a Worm that did not hatch that had the spoil warning once in year 1, everything else was ok. I didn't have any experience with the stress side, I was feeding lots of mint, mango, and nuts oil.
Back when Tecmo had the mini-guide on their website, it said no spoiling and no stress, then 30 cup jellies, then the very in the week of...
Anyway, this is a monster that can be difficult to get. I suspect that starting form can be a big factor.

By Kurasu Soratobu on Tuesday, May 30, 2000 - 10:42 am:

Freezing the monster has been proven not to keep then from transforming. In your case, your worm may have been stressed at the time it was supposed to coccoon, which is why it didn't.

There's no special time (that I know of) that it has to be born, though it will only cocoon in... summer, I think it is? Or am I remembering wrong? Mind's hazy on Beaclon-details today.

By Kurasu Soratobu on Tuesday, May 30, 2000 - 10:44 am:

Pardon the double-posting, but a couple questions I suddenly thought to ask:

1) What is the worm's present loyalty? It needs to be 80 or above.

2) What have you been feednig it?

3) What is its current level? A worm has to be rank D or lower (some people say 'C', but I go 'D' for safety) to coccoon.

By Lisa Shock on Tuesday, May 30, 2000 - 11:07 am:

DemonKnight, you might send it on a few errantries to pick up some techs. Since it's in its prime right now, it'll do well on errantry. That way, if you freeze it to make another monster, you'll get some carry-over. I raised two unsuccessful worms from CDs, then combined them to make a much better worm. I was really glad I'd sent the parents on the errantries, because my second generation started out far ahead of anything off a CD. Don't forget, you must feed at least 30 cup jelly, and never get the spoil warning. ("I guess it depends on us too much")

By Kurasu Soratobu on Monday, January 15, 2001 - 06:50 pm:

The Beaclon doesn't need fame at all (I created one with a worm who never battled in the least). It needs to be even, never be spoiled, never be stressed (although I'm wondering about that... but assume, just in case), needs to have a loyalty (not fame) of 80+, and needs to be fed at least 50 cup jellies.

Other than this, I really can't suggest what it needs.

Oh, and yes. You can send the worm on errantries. So long as you don't let it get too stressed out, and make sure it's rested (that could've been the problem) on June 1st.

By NeonMouko on Monday, January 15, 2001 - 07:19 pm:

How do I keep my monster from getting spoiled, then? I mean... I never can really tell except when she SAYS... (Yes, I'm new at the game).

By Petit-Trot on Monday, January 15, 2001 - 07:53 pm:

Scold, not always give them want they want and use Smoked Snakes. Those are 3 ways of not getting your monster spoiled.

For myself, I don't scold because I want bad natured monsters, and I give them what they want because I'm just too nice. So I use lots of Smoked Snakes.

By Mordred on Monday, January 15, 2001 - 10:50 pm:

You probably shouldn't give it at all. It can make your loyalty take a dive, plus by the time she says it it's really too late, and there are no warning signs. The only way to do it is to prevent it from getting spoiled at all. Like he said, scold them when they do anything wrong, and don't always give them what they want.

By Kurasu Soratobu on Wednesday, January 17, 2001 - 01:55 pm:

It may very well be, unfortunately. Try giving it another year and see what happens, although I'd say you'll need to make a new worm and try again.

If your creature is spoiled, the easiest way to tell is by seeing how long it's been 'soft' or above. If it's been there for over a week straight, then it's spoiled (at least, that's how I could always tell with mine). Plus, at the beginning of a new week, Colt'll say 'We're spoiling it too much' or ' depends on us too much. I guess we spoiled it.'

As for scolding them when they do something wrong, do so, but watch out for them to get 'strict'. That'll keep their loyalty at a level much like 'soft' will. Don't keep them 'strict' for too long, either.

Might wanna combine that worm away into something else (even a newborn) and get a new worm with multiple starting moves. At the very least, it'll give you a little boost.

As for being a newbie... we were all there once. Some of us, not so long ago.
